Navigation in desktop virtual environments: an evaluation and recommendations for supporting usability

Navigation in desktop virtual environments: an evaluation and recommendations for supporting usability

  • Angelia Sebok1,
  • Espen Nystad1 &
  • Stein Helgar1 

Virtual Reality volume 8, pages26–40(2004)Cite this article

  • 220 Accesses

  • 15 Citations

  • Metrics details

Abstract

Virtual reality (VR) can provide useful tools for a variety of applications. However, for these tools to be effective, they must be easy to use. In virtual environments (VEs), usability is impaired by poorly designed navigation systems. Insufficient realism and missing physiological orientation and motion cues impair spatial learning in desktop VEs. Capabilities for navigation in a VE are far more varied than in reality; so much greater flexibility can be offered, but designing VEs with too many options can overwhelm users. To assist designers in building effective, usable navigation systems for VEs, navigation techniques must be evaluated to identify which features actually support users in accomplishing their tasks and which features create unnecessary problems.

This study evaluates navigation in two different VEs to develop recommendations for the design of navigation systems in desktop VEs. The study consists of an objective assessment of navigation control dynamics, a guideline-based evaluation and a review of data collected during two experimental studies. The findings indicate that real-world constraints, specialised navigation techniques and feedback regarding location and direction of travel are needed to support navigation in desktop VEs.

Introduction

Virtual reality (VR) technology can be used to support work in a variety of situations. Examples of VR applications include tools to facilitate control centre design, to plan tasks in hazardous environments and to train workers. However, for these tools to be effective, they need to be usable. They must be designed so that the people using them can easily learn how to interact with the system to accomplish their tasks. A major component of usability, particularly important in virtual environments (VEs), is navigation [4]. Users must be able to determine their present location, find where they want to go, plan the route and traverse the route; they must be able to navigate in the VE. However, navigation systems in VEs are generally not sufficiently well designed to support users in these tasks [25]. This section addresses underlying issues regarding navigation, to provide the basis for identifying why navigation is a problem, what specific aspects of navigation cause problems for users and how navigation should be designed to best support VE users.

Navigation and spatial awareness

Navigation, whether in reality or in a VE, consists of a set of cognitive and physical tasks that a person performs to get from one location to another. These tasks include orientation (determining one’s present location and viewpoint), wayfinding (determining where one wants to go and planning how to get there) and travelling (actually moving through the environment to reach the destination). Orientation and wayfinding are primarily cognitive tasks, as the navigator must compare information in the visual scene with a mental map to determine present location and plan the route. Travelling is a physical task, in which the navigator actually moves from one location to another [3].

To accomplish orientation and wayfinding, the VE user must build a mental map of the VE [1]. In reality, people build mental maps by acquiring different types of information. The lowest level of spatial knowledge is landmark knowledge; this develops when a person becomes familiar with particularly salient features or landmarks in an area. Once the person has a sense of where landmarks are located, he/she can begin to develop route knowledge; knowing how to get to a specific destination. Finally, when a person has developed route knowledge of different paths, he/she begins to build configuration knowledge, or an understanding of the area layout [22]. Configuration knowledge is expressed as a mental map. The more accurate and complete the configuration knowledge, the more useful the mental map.

This type of spatial learning can occur in the previously described sequence, or it can be supported by tools, such as maps, which provide configuration knowledge directly [24]. While it is rare that a person can look at a map and translate all the information to the actual environment, a map can help the person to locate landmarks relative to one another, identify routes and begin developing a reasonably accurate mental map.

Navigation in VEs

Navigation in the virtual world is typically modelled after real-world navigation. Intuitively, this appears to be a reasonable metaphor, since users have a great deal of experience navigating in the real world. However, various aspects of VR technology make learning spatial information more difficult in a VE compared to the real environment. Virtual environments lack the cues for distance, motion and direction that are present in the real environment [3]. Shadow, texture and relative size are often insufficiently represented in VEs to provide useful depth and distance cues [15]. Furthermore, the relatively narrow field of view of most desktop VEs limits the amount of the visual scene that the user can see at one time, and, thus, makes it more difficult for users to develop an understanding of the area [1]. Because desktop VEs (at least the type reviewed in the present study) are actually 2D representations, users lack the binocular depth cues that they experience in reality, leading to users typically underestimating distances in VEs [11, 26, 27]. These problems can lead to inaccurate mental representations of the VE [15].

Further, navigators in VEs lack the bodily cues for motion (vestibular and kinaesthetic senses) that inform them of their present orientation and travel path velocity [21]. This mismatch between the visual and vestibular/kinaesthetic sensory information contributes to simulator sickness [12, 23], and can also contribute to incorrect understanding of movement and orientation in the VE.

Given the differences between navigation in VEs and reality, both in terms of presentation of the environment and interaction techniques, it appears that “making a VE like the real world” and expecting users to learn a VE layout in the same way as they learn in the physical environment is a simplistic and ineffective approach. Virtual reality offers many capabilities that are not fully exploited if the designer follows “the way it is in the real world.” In VEs, information presentation and interaction capabilities are far greater than in reality. While there certainly are problems and limitations with VEs, many possibilities exist for overcoming these challenges.

Tools and techniques to support navigation in VEs

Baker and Wickens [1, p.11] state that “effective support for navigation enables the VE traveller to answer the questions:

  • Where am I now (position, attitude, orientation)?

  • Where do I want to go?

  • How do I get there?”

To support users in knowing where they are and where they want to go, techniques and design features are available to help them understand the area, develop spatial awareness and see his/her present location with respect to the area. Salient landmarks help navigators develop landmark knowledge. Signposts and labels help navigators develop route knowledge and maps or top-down views help users develop configuration knowledge. Maps with you-are-here information help users orient themselves with respect to the entire area [1, 7].

To help users understand how they arrived at their present location in a VE, it is useful to show them how their present location relates to their previous location. This can be done by providing visual momentum during navigation between viewpoints. This concept [28] is from the film industry and refers to “continuity from one view to another” [17]. When users travel from one point to another in the VE, visual momentum can support users in developing a mental model of the environment. Conversely, if visual momentum is poor, e.g. if the visual scene suddenly changes completely, the user will have to determine his/her new location and consider how this relates to his/her previous location. Without visual momentum, the user has to re-orient himself/herself when he/she navigates to a new location.

Visual momentum in VEs becomes relevant in several situations: with any type of navigation where the user selects a destination and is automatically transported to the new location; if the user is able to move through objects in the VE (i.e. no collision avoidance in the model); with slow-updating virtual models, where the user attempts to move and then has to wait for the computer to display his/her action (i.e. jumping navigation).

Wayfinding or route planning is supported when users have developed an accurate mental map of the area. It might take time before users develop a reasonably-accurate map of a VE, so other computerised tools, such as search functionality or target selection capability, can assist users.

In a desktop VE, the user navigates by issuing commands via a control device (e.g. a mouse, keyboard, soft controls). In a VE that closely approximates real-world constraints, a navigation system can allow the user to walk through the VE. The user would follow only routes; he/she would be unable to walk through objects or to fly. However, this severely constrains movement and, whilst it keeps movement “like the real world”, it does not take advantage of any of the potential flexibility of the computerised environment.

In a VE, users can fly to the top of a room to examine the layout from a bird’s- eye-view; in reality, they must refer to blueprint drawings to obtain the same perspective. This view has advantages in allowing users to form configuration knowledge directly (i.e. to get an overview of the spatial information). Movement in a VE is potentially unconstrained, unlike reality, where gravity and the location of objects constrain movement to the x-z plane. Other than a person’s ability to crouch down, stand on their toes or climb a ladder, movement in the y direction is extremely limited. Furthermore, the ability to move through walls, ceilings and floors could save experienced users considerable time in navigating a virtual building, as opposed to being constrained to “walking” up and down virtual staircases. However, these techniques have not been evaluated to identify if they are actually effective ways to implement usable navigation, or if they are simply technological possibilities that offer no advantage in terms of usability.

Technical issues in navigation

In a VE, travel is implemented by means of control devices. Thus, control design issues need to be considered because of their ability to affect user performance. Direction-of-movement relationships, types of movement, control system order and deadspace [6] are all relevant in VEs.

Direction-of-movement relationships, the relationship between the way the user moves the control device and the corresponding movement in the display, are particularly important in desktop VEs. A typical input device used for desktop systems is a mouse, which allows movement in two dimensions—in the x-z plane. However, movement in the VE is often in three dimensions; users are able to move up and down (i.e. along the y-axis) in addition to moving in the x-z plane.

Types of movement in a VE, as described by [18], can be characterised in terms of the heading of the virtual body (Hb), the direction of view (Hv) and the direction of travel (Ht). In real-world navigation, these three concepts are independent (\({\text{H}}_{{\text{b}}} \ne {\text{H}}_{{\text{v}}} \ne {\text{H}}_{{\text{t}}} \)). In VR, these types of movement are typically constrained. Users are generally able to move and look in the same direction in which the body is oriented (i.e. Hb=Hv=Ht) [7]. Another common constraint in VR is to allow users to move in the direction in which the virtual body is aligned, whilst allowing the user freedom to look in a different direction (i.e. \({\text{H}}_{{\text{t}}} = {\text{H}}_{{\text{b}}} \ne {\text{H}}_{{\text{v}}} \)) (Bowman et al. 1997, as cited in [18]).

Control system order is a hierarchy of control relationships between the movement of the control and the resulting action in the display. Human performance in these systems has generally been assessed in terms of tracking tasks. The findings are that people do equally well with zero-order and first-order systems, but performance deteriorates significantly with second-order (and beyond) systems [19]:

-:

Zero-order controls. Position controls give a change in position in the display with a change in position of the control. That is, the user changes position by moving the control.

-:

First-order controls. Rate controls allow the user to control his/her rate of movement in the display. If the user moves the control slightly, he/she moves slowly through the display. If the user moves the control significantly, he/she moves quickly through the display.

-:

Second-order controls. Acceleration controls provide a change in acceleration in the display with a change in position of the control. If the user moves the control device slightly, acceleration is low (velocity is nearly constant). If the user moves the control device a significant distance, acceleration is rapid, allowing the user to traverse large distances.

Deadspace is an area around the null position of a control that will cause no corresponding change in the display. It provides smooth movement in sensitive displays (where a small change in control position results in a large change in the display) in that slight hand tremors on the control do not affect position in the display. The user must make sufficiently large movements (depending on the size of the deadspace) for the change to appear on the display. However, large deadspace areas can impair performance by forcing users to make overshooting control movements [19].

Summary

Given the diverse capabilities for navigation in VEs, it might be tempting for designers to include a great number of features and let users choose among them. Unfortunately, this approach will almost certainly lead to a less usable system than one with a number of reasonable constraints. Effective user-centred design requires achieving a careful balance between providing options and flexibility while at the same time minimising the user’s cognitive burden. This study evaluates navigation in desktop VEs to identify what issues will improve perceived usability and which features hinder user performance.

Methods

The sources for this analysis include evaluations of navigations systems and a review of two experimental studies. The VEs were directly compared through an objective evaluation (i.e. based on navigation dynamics and interaction techniques) and a guideline-based evaluation. The results of two experiments on control room verification in desktop VEs were reviewed, together with the evaluation results, for an understanding of navigation in VEs.

Evaluation of navigation in the VEs

Evaluation of navigation dynamics and interaction techniques

Navigation dynamics and interaction techniques were evaluated by actually working with the navigation systems and identifying specifically how navigation was implemented according to a set of criteria, as shown in Table 1.

Guideline-based evaluation

Four sets of guidelines for navigation in VEs were identified [10, 2, 20, 25]. These were reviewed and the guidelines relevant to desktop VEs were included in the following list, which provided the basis for a guideline-based evaluation of the VEs:

  • Provide a map of the VE, showing the user’s position and orientation [10, 20]

  • Avoid mode-based navigation [10]

  • Allow concurrent task execution [10]

  • Avoid the use of teleportation; provide smooth transitional motion between locations [10, 2]

  • Use target-specification techniques [2]

  • Constrain the user’s travel to two dimensions, if possible [2]

  • Enable flexible control of speed [20]

  • Indicate the direction of movement [20]

  • Allow the user to turn without losing orientation [20]

  • Permit easy reversal of actions (e.g. undo) [20]

  • Provide intuitive, easy-to-use buttons, icons, etc. on the interface [20]

  • Ensure that all tools that provide core functionality to the user are visible on the interface

  • Provide instantaneous visual feedback to movement [20]

  • Include landmarks (visually distinctive, concrete objects) [25]

Control room verification

Overview of studies

The phase 1 experiment was conducted to evaluate the feasibility of using VR as a tool for performing control room guideline verifications [9]. Subjects participated in two conditions: they performed control room verifications in a real-world control room and in a VR model of the same control room. For the purposes of this study, only the VR condition is of interest.

The phase 2 control room verification study was performed as a follow-on study to phase 1 [16]. Participants performed guideline-based evaluations in a real-world control room and in a VR model of the same control room. Only the VR condition is evaluated in this present study.

Data collected

Background information

In both experiments, subjects indicated their level of experience with VR applications by selecting one of four descriptors: zero, novice user, medium level or experienced.

Usability questionnaire

Upon completing the VR portion of the experiment, subjects in both phases answered a questionnaire regarding VR system usability. This was based on a usability questionnaire developed by [5] and contained both subjective ratings and open-ended questions. For the open-ended questions, only the navigation-relevant responses are considered.

Navigation questionnaire

To assess navigation directly, a navigation questionnaire was developed. This contained subjective rating scales, a multiple-choice question and open-ended questions.

Participants

Phase 1

Fifteen subjects from the OECD Halden Reactor Project voluntarily participated in this experiment. Subjects were recruited from two sections working in the area of control room verification and validation. Of these 15 subjects, 14 completed the VR portion of the experiment.

Phase 2

Eighteen subjects from the OECD Halden Reactor Project voluntarily participated in the experiment. Six subjects were control room or field operators from the Halden Boiling Water Reactor, 12 were from sections working in the area of control room verification and validation. Four of the subjects had participated in the phase 1 study. Of the 18 subjects in phase 2, 16 completed the VR portion of the experiment.

Materials

Phase 1

Subjects used a VR application in which they could navigate, using a mouse and keyboard, in a VR model of a control room. The VR application was presented on a large screen display, using SONY multiscan projector, model VPH-G70. The VR application ran on a Pentium III PC (667 MHz, 256 MB RAM) with a Creative 3D Blaster GeForce 256 Annihilator PRO graphics card (32 MB SGRAM), giving a minimum refresh rate of 20 frames/sec. The model of the control room had a geometric field of view of 50 degrees.

Phase 2

Subjects carried out their experimental tasks using a beta version of the CREATE 2 Verification Tool [8]. This tool presented the guidelines, the VR model of the control room and integrated virtual measurement tools. The computer used during the experiment was a Pentium III 733 MHz machine with 256 MB RAM and an Nvidia Quadro graphics card with 64 MB of memory. The software was displayed on a 21 in CRT screen.

The VR application used in phase 2 was different from that used in phase 1. Due to problems identified after the first study, the navigation system was redesigned and additional verification tools were included.

Experimental Procedure

Phase 1

Prior to participating in an experimental session, subjects received a briefing about the purpose of the experiment, subjects provided their background information. The subjects were then given a 25-minute training and familiarisation session. They were given a map of the control room and received a short tour of the VR model. Subjects were also instructed how to navigate in the model and how to use the tools in the application to perform verification tasks. They were allowed to practice navigating and using the tools. Following this introduction, the subjects performed the verification. When they had finished the VR task, they completed the usability questionnaire.

Phase 2

The procedure used in phase 2 was the same as that used in phase 1 with the addition of another questionnaire. Upon completion of the experimental session, the subjects completed both the usability questionnaire and the navigation questionnaire.

Analyses

When the data from the experiments were gathered, analyses were performed to characterise the results and, where appropriate, determine significance levels.

VR experience

In both testing conditions, subjects reported their level of VR experience by choosing one of four descriptor words (i.e. zero, novice user, medium level or experienced). No anchors or descriptions of what each level constituted were given; subjects were free to choose the word they felt best matched their experience level.

Usability ratings

The first part of the usability questionnaire required subjects to rate their disagreement/agreement with four statements on a five-point scale (1 indicated strongly disagree, 5 indicated strongly agree):

  1. 1.

    I needed to learn a lot of things before I could get going with this system

  2. 2.

    I thought the system was easy to use

  3. 3.

    I found the system unnecessarily complex

  4. 4.

    I found the various functions in this system were well integrated

Two of the questions (i.e. 1 and 3) asked about usability problems and the other two (i.e. 2 and 4) asked about positive usability aspects. Thus, the meaning of a high or low score differed, depending on the particular question.

To facilitate data interpretation, the questionnaire data were normalised so that a high score would indicate agreement that the system was usable. The data for each question were averaged across subjects in the particular condition. An ANOVA was performed to determine if there were differences in subject responses between the two experimental phases.

Navigation Ratings

The navigation questionnaire contained several questions that were answered by subjects indicating a number on a five-point rating scale, with higher ratings generally indicating a positive response. Navigation ratings were also divided into sub-categories based on user expertise, and averaged across subjects (with a particular self-reported expertise level) for each question. Data were plotted on a graph, showing the average rating by expertise group for each question. Further analysis was performed using a Mann-Whitney U test to identify significant differences among the groups of subjects for individual questions.

Qualitative questionnaire data

Qualitative questionnaire data were reported as participant comments. Positive comments were elicited by asking subjects “what did you like about the system?” Negative comments were gathered by asking “what did you dislike about the system?” and “how would you improve the system?” The wording of this last question allowed subjects to give suggestions or recommendations rather than directly criticising the design.

The comments that the subjects provided were categorised into themes rather than transcribed directly. In phase 1 and phase 2, the number of comments related to that category were counted and identified. The number of positive and negative questions were totalled and compared between phase 1 and phase 2 using a chi-square test.

Results

Evaluation of Navigation Dynamics and Interaction Techniques

Virtual environments

Figures 1 and 2 show the VEs presented in phase 1 and phase 2, respectively. These figures show a view of the VE and the control mechanisms for interacting and navigating.

Comparison of navigation tools and techniques

Table 2 shows a comparison of the features of the VEs used in phase 1 and phase 2 experiments.

Identification and description of the navigation tools

In both VEs evaluated, the user had a set of tools available for navigating. These included landmarks, a navigation mode selector button, a straighten button and various other buttons.

The landmarks are a set of pre-defined viewpoints that the user can access via a pull-down menu. When the user selects one of these landmarks, the view in the control room changes to the pre-defined viewpoint. This provides the with user a shortcut for returning to a familiar starting point. In phase 1, four landmarks were available. When the user selected a landmark in phase 1, the scene presented in the VE changed instantaneously to the new viewpoint. In the phase 2 VE, users had access to seven landmarks. When these were selected, the user appeared to “fly” to the new position.

Both the phase 1 and phase 2 VEs required users to select a navigation mode before they could move about in the VE. Both systems provided a straighten tool that allowed users to re-align the line of sight to the x-z plane.

The phase 1 system offered users a turn-to tool; a technique for selecting a target. This changed the user’s line of sight and direction of travel, but it did not move the user closer to the object.

The phase 2 system provided buttons, shown on the display, to allow navigation. These indicated the three types of movement allowed in the VE (e.g. walking, tilting, panning). Users could navigate by clicking on these soft buttons, or by using the corresponding buttons on the mouse. In contrast, the phase 1 system did not present buttons on movement; users were trained to use the mouse and keyboard to move in the VE. Both systems allowed the same types of movement, but in the phase 1 system, rotation about the x-axis could only be implemented by changing the direction of gaze (i.e. turn-to). Neither system explicitly constrained movement to standing height in the x-z plane, but because it was relatively more difficult to implement in phase 1, users were practically constrained.

Both the phase 1 and phase 2 systems coupled the direction of movement and direction of gaze. Users were not able to look around the VE without changing their travel path. Furthermore, both systems lacked collision avoidance; users were able to go through objects in the VEs.

Differences were identified in the controls of the phase 1 and phase 2 navigation systems. Phase 1 was zero-order and phase 2 was first-order. The phase 1 controls included no deadspace, whereas the phase 2 controls did.

Results of the usability rating scale

No significant differences in usability ratings were identified between the two experimental studies.

Results of the usability questionnaire

When subjects answered the usability questionnaire, they offered several comments specifically on navigation. In the phase 1 study, 13 of the 14 participants made navigation-related comments. In the phase 2 study, 13 of the 16 subjects offered navigation-related comments.

Table 3 presents the positive and negative comments made in both the phase 1 and phase 2 studies, and identifies the number of subjects in each study who made the comment.

Table 4 shows the total numbers of positive and negative comments made regarding navigation in phase 1 and phase 2. The table shows how phase 1 subject responses compare with phase 2 responses.

In phase 2, the subjects made more positive comments and fewer negative comments than the subjects in phase 1. The chi-square test for the navigation-related comments revealed a significant difference: χ 2(1, 46)=4.44; p=0.04.

Results of the navigation questionnaire

Phase 1

No navigation questionnaire was administered during phase 1.

Phase 2

The navigation questionnaire, similar to the usability questionnaire, included rating scales, multiple choice questions and open-ended questions. Of the 16 subjects who participated in phase 2, 11 completed the navigation questionnaire.

Rating scale

The rating scale questions asked the subject to evaluate various aspects of the navigation system. These were as follows (italics are added for easy comparison with Fig. 3):

  • Overall, how would you rate navigation in this system?

  • How effective did you find navigation to be? (e.g. could you move from one place to another? Could you move quickly and easily, without problems?)

  • How easy or difficult did you find it to move to a certain area in the control room (e.g. to go around a corner, to back up and get a better overview)

  • How smooth or choppy did you find it to be when controlling navigation?

  • What is your opinion about the speed?

  • What did you think about the mouse navigation controls?

  • What did you think about the soft button navigation controls?

  • What did you think about the landmarks navigation controls?

Overall, the subjects rated navigation as slightly positive (average of 3.6 out of 5.0). This average excludes the question regarding speed of navigation, since it is the only question where a high number does not indicate a positive rating.

Figure 3 shows the average ratings on the questions, divided by self-reported participant VR experience. As a general trend, the most experienced participants rated navigation most favourably on nearly all aspects. The average rating of experienced participants was 4.4, compared with 3.2 for the less experienced subjects.

This difference between experienced and less experienced users was significant for the overall question on navigation (U=2.0; p=0.02) and the question regarding ease of navigation (U=3.0; p= 0.03). For these questions, the experienced subjects rated overall navigation as 5.0, compared with 3.1 for less experienced subjects. The experienced subjects rated ease of navigation as 4.5, compared with 2.6 for the less experienced subjects.

The one question where experienced VR users did not indicate the highest rating (speed), was the one for which a middle rating (3) would be the most favourable.

Open-ended questions

The navigation questionnaire included open-ended questions to obtain user input regarding various issues in navigation. The responses are divided into three categories, identified below. The number in parentheses indicates the number of subjects with the same answer.

Good features:

  • Fast, efficient navigation (once learned) (5)

  • Landmarks were useful (4)

  • It was no problem to move in an unrestricted manner (4)

  • Reasonably intuitive functioning/understanding what happens (4)

  • Good to use only the mouse buttons to navigate (1)

  • Cursor feedback regarding mode of navigation (fly, tilt, pan) (1)

Problems:

  • Learning/practice is necessary (7)

  • Movement was restricted/split unnaturally (7)

  • Difficult to move around in the room (5)

  • Fine tuning at close range is difficult (3)

  • Disappeared into the walls, became disoriented (2)

  • Mouse speed was too fast (2)/too slow (1)

  • Easy to move height by accident/difficult to maintain level position (2)

  • Impossible to navigate and measure at the same time (1)

  • Too many modes and functionalities (1)

  • Missed pop-up explanatory labels for buttons (1)

  • Can rotate too quickly (1)

Suggestions:

Landmarks:

  • Include relevant names on landmarks, not simply numbers (6)

  • Include a map of landmarks/overview (with viewing angle) (5)

  • Include task-relevant/user-defined landmarks (3)

  • Include more landmarks (2)

Constraints:

  • Needs more limitations (in general, gravity, collision avoidance) (3)

  • Include functionality for moving back to a horizontal alignment, eye height above the floor (1)

Features to add/change:

  • Use a joystick (2)

  • Include a search functionality (1)

  • Need adjustable mouse/travel speed (1)

  • Show a 2D map showing position in the room (1)

  • Show several views from the same position (1)

Discussion

User impressions of navigation

Users generally found the navigation system in the phase 2 VE to be superior to that of the phase 1 VE. On the usability questionnaire, participants in phase 2 made more positive comments (i.e. total number of comments) than participants in phase 1. Further, the responses indicate that phase 2 navigation was generally perceived as more usable. In phase 1, subjects’ comments were very general, along the lines of “navigation is easy” or “navigation is difficult”, without any further explanation. In phase 2, subjects who claimed that navigation was difficult could point to specific problems, such as “going through walls and becoming disoriented” or “moving too fast”, as reasons for the difficult navigation. These more detailed answers in phase 2 indicate that the subjects had a better understanding of the how the navigation system worked, and, thus, were able to offer more insightful comments.

Potential explanations

The navigation system used in phase 1 differed from that used in phase 2. These differences are likely to be significant contributors to the different user impressions.

Controls

Explicit controls, as opposed to hidden functionality, are recommended in usability literature [13] to “bridge the gulf of execution” [14]—i.e. to clearly show the user what actions are possible. Guidelines [20] also recommend the use of explicit controls for navigation. In the phase 1 system, a number of control functionalities were hidden. They were accessed solely via the mouse buttons or the Alt key and left mouse button. However, in the phase 2 applications, all navigation capabilities were explicitly represented in the interface. They were also accessible as mouse buttons, but these were redundant capabilities. Users in phase 2 appeared to have a better understanding of how to navigate the VE and what actions were possible, compared to users in phase 1.

Another difference in the navigation controls between the two VE systems was that the phase 2 system allowed users to navigate using only the mouse. The phase 1 VE, however, required users to use the keyboard (i.e. Alt key) and soft controls on the display (i.e. turn-to) as well as the mouse to implement the same movement capabilities. While the multiple controls requirement was not identified by users as a problem with the phase 1 navigation, the phase 2 navigation questionnaire revealed the usefulness of a single control device. In phase 2, ten of eleven subjects used only the mouse buttons to navigate and this capability was specifically mentioned as a positive attribute of the navigation system.

Dynamics

Order

In phase 1, the control dynamics were zero-order (position), and in phase 2, they were first-order (velocity). This is obviously not something that users would specifically address in their comments, so other findings must be considered.

The difference in the order of control meant that users in phase 2 did not have to move the mouse continuously when moving in the control room. Once they had begun navigating, they could simply keep the mouse button pressed to continue moving in the same direction. However, in phase 1, users had to move the mouse whenever they wanted to move in the VE; they had to start and stop repeatedly. This contributed to a “bumpy” appearance when navigating.

Further, the zero-order control system in phase 1 did not have deadspace; any unintentional movement of the mouse was registered as movement in the VE. This created a jittery appearance during navigation.

While research in this particular area appears scarce, one experiment, Fairchild et al. (1993) as cited in [10], specifically investigated the use of a body-centred, first-order control system that allowed movement in the VE to be controlled by the user’s leaning. The direction of lean established orientation in the VE and the distance of lean established travel velocity (i.e. first-order control). These researchers concluded that leaning was a “stunningly effective navigation paradigm.” This navigation system corresponds to the control mechanisms in the phase 2 study. The user moves the mouse in the direction of interest, and the amount of movement corresponds to the speed of travel. These researchers and the present study both found first-order control systems to be effective and useful for navigation in VEs.

Movement planes and rotation

In both studies, subjects experienced difficulties when they were trying to achieve a certain viewpoint in the VE. This was partly because they could not rotate and move at the same time. To get to a target location, the user had to first navigate to the area, then rotate, then, realizing that the viewpoint was not quite right, move again. The users continued this process until they either achieved the orientation or decided that they were close enough and quit. The way in which the movements were divided in the VE was not natural and required familiarisation. Guidelines do not offer specific advice on how to implement control dynamics, and this does appear to be a problem area.

Speed of movement

Speed of movement was mentioned by participants in the phase 2 experiment as a problem with navigation. Of the subjects who commented on speed, most claimed that navigation was too fast. Subjects recommended that the speed should be adjustable and selectable by the user. Guidelines also recommend that speed should be selected by the user [20].

This was an interesting finding, indicating a problem that can be, perhaps, be resolved by training and familiarisation. The navigation speed in the phase 2 study was, in fact, variable, depending on how much the user moved the cursor. These user comments indicate that participants were not aware of how the navigation system worked. Perhaps users must be informed, explicitly, about the first-order control (displacement of cursor controls speed of movement) and simply allowed more time to become familiar with the dynamics.

Another possible solution is to change the control dynamics so as to allow a constant rate of movement through the VE, regardless of cursor displacement. This would fit with the apparent expectation that the subjects have about how navigation works. There would need to be a default rate at which the movement occurs, and the users should be provided with an adjustable scale. This would provide a more explicit solution for allowing users to control navigation speed.

Independent line of sight

Guidelines recommend that users should be able to change the line of sight without changing the direction of travel [20]. In the VEs reviewed in this study, users changed direction of travel if they changed gaze direction. The lack of an independent line of sight was not identified as a problem by subjects, but this could be due to the tasks they were performing. If the task required more exploring, e.g. learning the layout of an area, this capability might be more important.

Constraints

The VE navigation guidelines recommend that designers constrain movement to two dimensions (i.e. the x-z plane) when possible [2] to reduce the cognitive burden on users. The phase 1 navigation system did constrain movement this way, to the extent that it was rather difficult to change orientation (i.e. required the use of the turn-to button and selection of an appropriate target). Constrained movement, or gravity, was not implemented in phase 2 and appears to have been a problem. Users of the phase 2 system indicated that they often found themselves “floating” up or down when they had intended to navigate in a straight line.

None of the guidelines specifically mentioned collision avoidance, but this appears to be another necessary constraint to support navigation in VEs. In general, users became confused by going through objects, which suggests that collision avoidance would help usability by constraining movement.

Feedback

Transition between discrete points

One difference between the phase 1 and phase 2 systems was in the implementation of the landmarks functionality. In phase 1, when a user selected a landmark, the view shifted automatically to the new location. The design solution implemented in phase 2 provided continuity (i.e. visual momentum) between the two views and, perhaps, gave the user additional information about the VE, helping him/her to build a mental map of the area.

Gabbard and Hix [10] refer to the type of navigation offered by the landmarks functionality as point-to-point navigation and recommend that the automatic navigation between specific points be animated as a flight path. This type of navigation is a trade-off between speed and flexibility of navigation versus situation awareness [1]. Bowman [2] specifically recommends that designers “avoid the use of teleportation”, because users become disoriented when the viewpoint changes suddenly, without showing the transitional information.

In phase 1, users did not specifically comment on the landmarks feature, which implies that they did not use it. If they had used it and found it helpful, they would probably have mentioned it as a positive feature. When phase 2 subjects were asked “what did you like about navigation?”, the most-frequently mentioned positive feature was landmarks. Because the main difference between the landmarks feature in the two models was the way in which the view was shifted (i.e. discrete, instantaneous versus continuous, flying), the perceived improvement is quite likely due to this difference. The sudden change of scene in the phase I VE could confuse users, forcing them to re-orient themselves in the new viewpoint.

Information presentation

The guidelines recommended that various types of information be presented to users to support navigation. Sayers et al. [20] recommend the use of top-down views or “you are here” maps to show the user’s position and orientation with respect to the VEs. Further, Gabbard and Hix [10] suggest that users be provided with information to help them determine their position, attitude and orientation. In VEs with unconstrained movement in the y direction, it is also necessary to provide users with feedback regarding their height above the floor.

The findings in the two studies support these recommendations. Subjects in both studies indicated that they had problems knowing their present location or direction of travel. Phase 2 subjects experienced problems with identifying their orientation. A recommendation from the phase 2 study was that the VE include a top-down view map to indicate location.

Other recommended information includes feedback regarding direction of travel [20]. This was partially implemented in phase 2, where users saw one of three different cursors, depending on their direction of travel. However, a more salient way to present direction of travel could be to include it in a “you are here” map.

Physical landmarks, in the sense of prominent features in the environment, are also recommended to support navigation in VEs [25]. In both the phase 1 and phase 2 VEs, features such as a control station provided these landmarks. These appeared helpful, but were perhaps less critical in these relatively small VEs. Landmarks become considerably more important in large VEs where users are more likely to become lost.

Flexibility

Concurrent task execution

Guidelines recommend that users be able to navigate and perform tasks concurrently [10]. This was not possible in the VEs reviewed in this study. The users had to select a mode and then either navigate or perform verification tasks individually; moving and working could not be performed simultaneously. This was mentioned as a potential improvement in the phase 2 study.

Easy reversal of actions

The VEs reviewed in this study lacked undo functionality. In discrete navigation, the meaning of “undo” is clear: undo the previous action. However, in a continuous navigation system, the concept of undo has meaning only in certain circumstances. If a user has been navigating continuously for, e.g. twenty seconds, and then hits undo, presumably, he/she does not want to return to the starting point but to a particular point passed on the journey. This implementation would not be reasonable to achieve. The guidelines recommend that an undo capability be included in VEs [20], but lack guidance on how this should be implemented.

Target selection techniques

The guidelines recommend that VEs include functionality for users to select a target [10, 2]. To a limited extent, via the use of landmarks, this was implemented in the VEs evaluated in this study. Landmarks appeared to be a useful feature for navigation in the phase 2 study.

Navigation and usability

No significant differences were identified in the usability ratings between phase 1 and phase 2. This conflicts with the navigation-related comments gathered from the usability questionnaire, where subjects offered more positive comments on phase 2 navigation than on phase 1.

Two of the questions on the usability rating scale asked specifically about the complexity of the system. Question 1 asked if the user “needed to learn a lot of things to get going” and question 3 asked if the user “found the system unnecessarily complex.” The virtual control room in phase 1 had far fewer capabilities and functionalities than the phase 2 model. In phase 1, there were six buttons/pull down menus; in phase 2, however, there were 14 buttons/pull down menus in total. The additional capabilities in phase 2 increased the complexity of the system and, thus, increased participants’ learning requirements.

The fact that there were no significant differences in rated usability, even when the phase 2 system offered many additional capabilities, is interesting. When considered together with the navigation results (that the subjects identified more positive features of navigation in the phase 2 VE) these findings suggest that navigation improvements to the phase 2 system offset the additional complexity, resulting in overall unchanged usability ratings.

Experienced user ratings

One interesting find from the phase 2 navigation questionnaire is that experienced VR users rated the navigation as significantly better than less experienced users. This could indicate that practice and familiarisation with the navigation system will improve perceived usability, that it simply is a matter of “getting used to it.”

Guidelines

The VEs evaluated in this study did not closely follow design recommendations set forth in the guidelines. A number of the problems that users encountered and suggestions they made for improving navigation were related to the not-followed guidelines (e.g. constrained movement, a “you are here” map). Particularly useful features (e.g. landmarks in the sense of viewpoints) were often related to areas where the guidelines had been followed.

Not all problems were accounted for in the guidelines, however. Collision avoidance was not addressed and this was a significant problem. Furthermore, there was no guidance on integrating navigation control capabilities into a single input device. This is good design practice and was noted as a strength of the phase 2 system.

However, this is not to say that simply following the guidelines will result in more usable navigation systems. The guidelines generally offered quite detailed information about particular aspects of navigation (e.g. transporting rather than flashing to a new viewpoint), while ignoring other, perhaps more critical issues (e.g. degrees of freedom of movement and how to implement them). Furthermore, some problems that users identified were not addressed in guidelines (e.g. collision avoidance). Finally, guidelines are simply guidance; they need to be tailored to each individual task situation; when the task requires 3D movement, e.g. the capability to fly, then constraining motion to two dimensions will be unacceptable.

Overall findings

Good navigation is necessary, but not sufficient, for good usability. The importance of navigation to overall perceived usability is related to the relevance of navigation to the main tasks that the user is trying to accomplish with the system. If navigation is difficult to perform, perceived usability will be low. However, as the usability ratings in phase 1 and phase 2 show, other factors affect perceived usability.

It is important to note that users had very little practice on using the VR systems evaluated in this study. The results of this study indicate that experienced users were more satisfied with the systems than inexperienced users, implying that additional familiarisation will improve perceived usability. On the other hand, it also appears that many potential improvements can be made to support user navigation.

Usable navigation systems in desktop VEs appear to require more constraints and more information than that implemented in the systems evaluated in this study. Constraining movement to the x-z plane and including collision avoidance appear necessary. Further, it appears that additional information is needed to support users in navigation tasks. Top-down “you are here” maps, showing orientation and direction of travel, were lacking. Additional navigation possibilities, such as target selection and the ability to turn without losing orientation, also appear to be useful.

Recommendations for design of navigation systems in VEs

Here is a summary of the useful features that can be incorporated into future navigation systems, suggested by the results of our research:

  • Include target-selection techniques

  • Include task-relevant landmarks (viewpoints) with meaningful names

  • Show the transition between current location and landmark (provide visual momentum)

  • Include collision avoidance (selectable, but the default option) – this will prevent users going through walls and becoming disoriented

    • Experienced users might find that the ability to go through objects provides a useful shortcut tool

  • Include gravity (selectable, but the default option) – this will constrain movement to follow the x-z plane

    • Experienced users might find that the ability to fly provides a useful shortcut tool

  • If the VE allows movement in the y direction, provide a “return to standing height” capability

  • Add an undo capability (even though it might be limited in applicability)

  • Include visual landmarks (prominent features) in the VE

  • Implement first-order (velocity) rather than zero-order (position) control systems. This allows the user to vary his/her rate of travel through the VE and prevents them from having to start and stop navigation

    • Alternatively, implement a navigation system that allows constant rate of travel, regardless of mouse displacement—make the speed adjustable by users

  • Allow the user to control the speed

  • Include small deadspaces or slightly reduce sensitivity (increase the C/R ratio) to smoothen navigation (so inadvertent hand movements will not appear as deviations along the travel path)

  • Include a simplified top-down view of the VE (e.g. a “you are here” map), clearly indicate the user’s current location and orientation

  • Include feedback about the current line of sight (direction of gaze)—if the user is looking slightly up or down

  • Include landmarks (viewpoints) in the “you are here” map; these could become visible when they are selected from a pull-down menu

  • Allow for the direction of view to be decoupled from the direction of travel and virtual body orientation. This will allow users to “look around” from various locations in the VE, without losing their orientation on a path

  • Integrate navigation capabilities into a single device (e.g. mouse, joystick)

  • Present all navigation options explicitly (as soft buttons). These should be redundant with hard control capabilities, but need to be explicitly shown and easy to understand; expert users should be allowed to hide the soft buttons

  • Provide feedback on the direction of travel (e.g. as with the cursors in the phase 2 VE or in a “you are here” map).

Further work

Leading on from this experiment, further research can be to:

  • Perform an experimental study to evaluate if these recommendations actually improve navigation and objective task performance.

  • Evaluate which factors (e.g. control dynamics, constraints, feedback, flexibility) are most critical to improving navigation.

  • Continue testing with users: in particular, study their ability to learn over time. Perhaps some of the problems with navigation are simply a matter of familiarisation with control dynamics in the VE.
